sections.title: Common Questions
content: Q: How do I interpret correlation in scatter plots? Correlation patterns: (1) Positive correlation - points trend upward right (as X increases, Y increases), examples: study time vs test scores, ad spend vs sales. (2) Negative correlation - points trend downward right (as X increases, Y decreases), examples: price vs demand, defect rate vs quality investment. (3) No correlation - random scatter, no clear pattern, X and Y independent. Strength: tight cluster around imaginary line = strong correlation, wide spread = weak correlation. Correlation â‰  causation: ice cream sales correlate with drowning deaths (both caused by hot weather, not each other). Use scatter plot to identify relationships, then investigate causation.

Q: Should I add a trend line or regression line to my scatter plot? Add trend line when: showing general relationship direction (positive/negative), presenting to non-technical audience (line clarifies pattern), quantifying correlation (display RÂ² value showing fit strength). Skip trend line when: no clear correlation (random scatter, line misleads), multiple clusters (single line oversimplifies), outliers heavily influence line (misleading fit). Types: linear (straight line, most common), polynomial (curved, for non-linear relationships), logarithmic (for exponential patterns). Always display equation and RÂ² value if showing trend line. Caution: trend lines can mislead if correlation is weak (RÂ² < 0.5) - visual pattern may suggest stronger relationship than exists.

Q: How do I choose appropriate axis scales for scatter plots? Scale considerations: (1) Start at zero vs focused range - scatter plots CAN use non-zero origin unlike bar charts (position matters, not length from baseline). (2) Equal vs different ranges - if X and Y use same units (height vs weight in cm), equal scales help, otherwise independent scales appropriate. (3) Linear vs logarithmic - log scale when data spans orders of magnitude (revenue: $100 to $10M), reveals patterns in wide-range data. (4) Aspect ratio - square plots (equal axis lengths) generally best for comparison. Guideline: choose scales that maximize use of chart area without distorting, include full data range plus small margin, label clearly if not starting at zero.

Q: What's the difference between scatter plots and bubble charts? Scatter plot: two variables (X, Y position), uniform point size, compares two metrics. Bubble chart: three variables (X position, Y position, bubble size), variable point size represents third dimension (sales volume, population, budget). Use scatter when: analyzing bivariate relationship, point size not meaningful, clarity priority (too many bubbles overlap and confuse). Use bubble when: third variable adds context (countries by GDP per capita vs life expectancy, bubble = population), audience sophisticated enough to read three dimensions. Caution: bubble size is hard to compare accurately (area perception), limit to 10-20 bubbles, avoid too much size variation (100x range hard to visualize).

Q: How many data points should I show on a scatter plot? Optimal ranges: 20-200 points for clear patterns and individual point inspection. Under 20 points: correlation unclear (random variation dominates), consider table instead. 20-100 points: ideal range (patterns visible, outliers identifiable, not cluttered). 100-500 points: usable with transparency/smaller points. Over 500 points: overplotting (points overlap obscuring patterns), use transparency, hexagonal binning, or density plots instead. For huge datasets (10k+ points): scatter plot shows density not individual points, consider heatmap or contour plot. Interactive tools help: zoom, filter, hover tooltips manage large datasets.

sections.title: Pro Tips & Best Practices
content: ðŸ’¡ Label outliers and notable data points for context: Outliers = most interesting points (exceptional performance, errors, special cases). Label them: add text annotations identifying what they represent (\"December holiday spike\", \"Data entry error\", \"Viral campaign\"). Without labels, viewers wonder: \"What's that point?\" Labels turn scatter plot from abstract to concrete, enable investigation of anomalies, spark discussion. Tools: direct labels near points, leader lines if crowded, hover tooltips for interactive. Selective labeling: don't label all points (cluttered), only notable ones (top 3, outliers beyond 2 standard deviations, examples of each cluster).

ðŸ’¡ Use color or shape to encode third variable or categories: Beyond X/Y position, encode additional dimension: color by category (product lines in different colors), shape by group (circles vs triangles for male vs female), size for magnitude (bubble chart). Benefits: reveals patterns within subgroups, answers \"Does correlation hold for all categories?\", adds analytical depth. Example: sales vs marketing spend colored by region - reveals some regions have better ROI. Limit: 3-5 colors/shapes maximum (more = confusing), include clear legend, ensure accessibility (don't rely on color alone, use shapes too).

ðŸ’¡ Add reference lines to divide chart into quadrants for analysis: Quadrant analysis: draw vertical + horizontal lines at meaningful thresholds (median, target, benchmark), divides chart into four regions. Example: customer segmentation (frequency vs spend) - high frequency/high spend (loyalists), high frequency/low spend (engaged but poor fit), low frequency/high spend (whales), low frequency/low spend (at-risk). Label quadrants with strategic implications. Use for: portfolio analysis (BCG matrix), prioritization (impact vs effort), performance evaluation (actual vs target). Makes scatter plot actionable: each quadrant gets different strategy.

ðŸ’¡ Consider using transparency when points overlap significantly: Overplotting problem: many points in same location appear as single point, hides density information. Solution: semi-transparent points (alpha 0.3-0.5) - overlapping points = darker shade, reveals concentration. Alternative: jitter (add small random offset to spread overlapping points), hexagonal binning (show count in hexagonal grid cells), contour plots (density lines like topographic map). When to use: 100+ points, data naturally clustered, precise position less important than density pattern. Balance: too transparent (hard to see single points), too opaque (overlap invisible).

ðŸ’¡ Document correlation coefficient and significance in chart title or caption: Statistical context makes scatter plot credible: include correlation coefficient (r = -0.87), RÂ² value (RÂ² = 0.76 means 76% of variance explained), p-value if relevant (p < 0.05 means statistically significant). Placement: subtitle below chart title, caption at bottom, or in corner of plot area. Audience-dependent: technical audience expects these statistics, general audience may skip. Caution: correlation stats assume linear relationship - if curve is non-linear, linear correlation misleading (use appropriate test: Spearman for monotonic, regression analysis for curves).

sections.title: When to Use This Tool
content: Marketing & Sales Analysis: Explore relationship between ad spend and revenue or ROI by campaign, analyze correlation between customer lifetime value and acquisition cost, visualize relationship between email frequency and engagement or unsubscribe rates

Scientific Research: Plot experimental variables to identify relationships in lab data, visualize correlation between environmental factors and outcomes, display distribution of measurements to identify outliers or patterns

Quality Control & Manufacturing: Analyze relationship between process parameters and defect rates, identify outliers in production data indicating quality issues, visualize correlation between material properties and performance

Financial Analysis: Explore correlation between risk and return in investment portfolios, analyze relationship between economic indicators for forecasting, visualize stock correlations or beta coefficients for diversification

Customer Analytics: Segment customers by purchase frequency vs average order value, analyze relationship between satisfaction scores and retention rates, visualize correlation between support tickets and churn risk

HR & Performance: Explore relationship between employee tenure and performance ratings, analyze correlation between training investment and productivity gains, visualize compensation vs performance for equity analysis
